segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Hey everyone, on behalf of Spectrops and the Spectrops crew, I'd like to thank you for
attending our first conference event, hopefully the first of many.
You know, obviously we've been going through this pandemic sort of situation for the last
several months, and early on, sort of like from a leadership perspective,
kind of sort of like a state of paralysis as you're dealing with all these company issues
and customers that are having issues, and how are you going to switch all your operations to
a specific method. Much of our crew got together and came up with this week of webinars in the
spring, kind of just, I don't know, do something positive, right? And, you know, I think I had a
dark time and hopefully something that like gave people a little bit of a distraction for a while.
And as we got into the summer, we looked at our year, we, you know, we want to take that further
and kind of focus us as a company on what we sort of wanted to do, right? What we wanted to
kind of do for the rest of the year, and kind of what could we do for a positive sort of thing
for the industry, and kind of focus everything down to that. So that's how we kind of came up
with this conference, and hopefully we enjoy it. The team has put a ton of work into this over the
last several months, and I kind of get to be the idea guy, right? So I sit there and say,
we should do this thing, and then just get to sit on the sidelines as everybody else gets to do it.
And it's, you know, I'm really happy and proud to see this amazing amount of work that the team
has put in place and done to produce this. So hopefully we enjoy it, and on behalf of the team,
again, I thank you for spending some time with us. Just a little bit of overview on the conference.
If you haven't seen it already, I kind of have a lobby for various places you can go.
You know, every year we try to do sort of like a charity, you know, like design a shirt and do a
charity, you know, sometimes, or do the proceeds, something that's important to us. And this year
we wanted to kind of expand that in conjunction with the conference. So we have our first sort
of swag store for our conference, and kind of a suite of charities that are important to us,
you know, with some very spectro-obscure, so feel free to check that out. And then kind of
recreate that lobby-com feel a little bit as best we could. So we set up a channel on
Bloodhound Slack. We'll be hanging out during the day on Friday. I mean, it's Wednesday since
I'm recording this, but we'll be all hanging out there, and you can chat with us, and hopefully
just have some fun. And then obviously all of these sessions are recorded so that people can
kind of view them at your leisure. Obviously a few tracks, so you can't go to every talk right away,
but they'll be up for a while on the conference site, and then on YouTube later. So we hope
everyone enjoys it. So a little bit about this talk outside of this conference. There's a good
chance you haven't seen me speak before. I'm Dave McGuire. I'm the CEO of Spectro-Obs, but
kind of like, I don't know, one of those like old warriors that just kind of sit around and talk
about like their glorious adventures in the past. That's pretty much where I'm at now. I'm not
going to tell you when I was last technically relevant. So you don't necessarily see me talk a
lot because we as a company, we really try to like let the work sort of speak for itself, right? And
not that I do a lot of work out there, so you probably wouldn't see me very often,
but we're putting this schedule together, coming up with what we wanted to talk about,
and our team was like, well, we need to do a keynote because the conference is due. And I was
like, that's a great idea. We should totally do a keynote. I'm like, well, yeah, you should do the
keynote. Oh, what the heck am I going to talk about? They go, you should do it. I'm like,
maybe we have somebody else do it. Nope, it's going to be you. All right. So sit down and think,
what can I have to say that's sort of interesting? One of the things that the
pandemic that was kind of, not that it's been good by any means, but one of the things that
kind of lets you do, I don't know if it's good, lets you sit and kind of focus on this existential
reflection, right? Which is, you know, like, what are we doing? Where are we going?
What are we doing today? And why are we doing it? And where do we come from? Because you remember
sort of what the normal world was like. And realize we hadn't really ever done that for
Spectrum, right? We never really sat and talked about, you know, what drives us, what motivates
us, those kinds of things. How do we see ourselves in the community? So I thought that might be
something, this could be a good chance to sort of do that in this format. I think it was this
clever title. I thought it was clever. Obviously called, How Did Ghosts Grow Up? I was immediately
reminded by our team that that's an oxymoron, because obviously ghosts don't grow up. I still
thought it was clever, so I kept it. But thinking about it, I actually had to go like develop my
content after that. And thinking about it, you're kind of like, well, it's true, ghosts don't grow up.
Honestly, you know, we're obviously playing off of like the Spectrops, you know, name for how
ghosts grow up. But like, companies don't grow up either, right? A company is a thing that exists.
So obviously our company isn't going to grow up, but people do. I grow up, and our folks do,
and people that join us bring new perspectives in. But also if you think about it, our community is
really growing up together as well. We're a very young community in general. Let me say less than
really effectively 30 years old. And if you look back at our history, we've made a ton of mistakes.
We've had some great victories, like you think. Our perspective has often changed, just like,
you know, a group of folks growing up. And so, you know, kind of from that, maybe what this
talk is about is maybe more of a story, right? It's a story about how we're growing up, how we,
Spectrops, are growing up. I mean, I've grown up some, and how our community has sort of grown up
as well, and how we see Spectrops sort of fitting into that picture of, you know, where maybe we
want to go. And so, you know, from an industry perspective, don't get me wrong, I'm a philosopher.
Nobody would ever certainly accuse me of that, nor would I characterize my views or our views
as sort of what's the entire industry. They only give you our perspective, give you my perspective.
I think it's even kind of dangerous a little bit to try to put a box around what our industry,
our community is, because that's often somewhat up for debate. So I'm not going to try to do that.
I'll be a little bit more vague. But, you know, if you think about it, spent some time ruminating
kind of on what are we doing? And, you know, where does our industry exist? You think,
you would come to realize that, like, we exist in this very unique community, right? This very
unique industry, because we sort of exist in this constant state of, like, asymmetrical warfare,
really, in that, you know, we're constantly dealing with attacks and defense, and how do
we deal with these threats that are sort of actively attacking us on a regular basis?
And kind of realize that, like, really, for us, everyone is in the fight. That's another thing
unique for situations that we have corporations and we're trying to defend organizations that
are really looking from a defense perspective. But we also have nation states involved. We have
criminal organizations. We have all kinds of, obviously, groups that are sort of involved in
this fight and tangentially a part of our community in some respects. Also that, like,
our victories in our young sort of lives have been really, really fleeting. Think about it.
You know, we may solve a problem. We may, you know, we may feel like we made two steps forward
in something, but oftentimes it only lasts for a little while, right? And, yeah, new attacks come
out. New methods of operations come out. This constant back and forth that we're in. I think
one of the most unique things about us is that, like, how exactly do we define what the good guys
and the bad guys are? I mean, at the end of the day, it really actually, for us, depends on
perspective. And so, like, your country, another country, our country, right? And then also
on a point in time. That's kind of interesting about us and the, like, significant component
of the industry that maybe at one point in time would not have been considered the good guys,
right? But that's sometimes a valuable perspective in us, and I don't think you see that too much in
other industries. Like I said, we're also really comparatively young and uninformed. I've been
doing this for 19 years, and that makes me basically ancient since I effectively joined
this industry. But really, even in that time, you know, we've grown so large, like, it's not
recognizable what it was, you know, 19 years ago for me. And not recognizable from the number,
the size that we've grown to, but the way that we're operating. And so, in some respects,
we're in this form where we're really still forming what we're going to be, you know,
when we grow up, kind of. What are our grandkids going to be doing in this industry? And so,
we're in a sort of, like, dynamic time that, in a lot of respects, is exciting and also frustrating,
obviously. I'm probably being a little bit nostalgic here, thinking back to my much younger
self, when, you know, and saying that, like, times are simpler. The problem sets that we
were dealing with was simpler. And in a lot of respects, that's true. But what strikes me the
most, kind of, is that, you know, my younger self, is that you sort of, or you felt you knew
what your job was, or you felt you knew that the mission, you're trying to make the world a safer
place. At the end of the day, I'll have all kinds of other motivations for what's going on.
There was a sense, sort of, that, like, we were going to solve problems. It was going to get
better. If you sort of look back at, you know, how things have gone over those number of years,
you can really come to see that, I think, like, oftentimes, we're just reacting, right? We're
like building the plane as we're flying it. And that makes us, you know, it makes us very
reactionary. It also makes it hard to say, what was the vision? Like, well, a vision that depended
on what was going on at that time. Concepts that, you know, we've been lucky to sort of, like,
ride the wave on, you know, with spectrops, like red teaming and hunting. You know, these military
concepts that sort of migrated into the civilian space, because of the type of asymmetric warfare
that we dealt with, you know, those kind of migrated along the way. It wasn't like 15 years
ago, we knew that these components were going to be big, or big components of what we as an
industry did. I think that's also made it really hard to, you know, that reactionary sort of
mentality we've been into. It's been really hard to see, like, three steps out, right? Okay, if we
do this thing, what's going to be the reaction to it? If we release this, what's going to be
the reaction to it? How's that going to affect things? We want to do, you know, we're doing
something to make, to help to make this thing better. But in the end of the day, two, three
steps down the line, you know, it could be used against you, right? It's really hard to see when
really we're just reacting around us. And, you know, you can't see three steps ahead when you
can barely see your own feet in the fog. And so, you know, this future implications of what we're
doing today can be really hard to see. When I say doing today, I'm talking about services that
you're offering, products you're building, open source tools that you're releasing, right? It can
be really hard to see where that goes somewhere down the road. And the stakes get a lot higher.
The industry is bigger. There's a lot more money involved. And a lot more opinions, diverse
opinions about how you should operate. And so that can kind of lead you to a little bit of a
paralysis sometimes of, like, I don't know what the right thing to do is. If I do this thing that
I think it'll make better, how many different ways might that affect things? And the answer is
oftentimes we don't know. But because we don't know, and the stakes are higher, makes you kind of
worry about what you're going to do. If you, you know, when I look at SpecterOps, we're a little
less than four years old at this point. Obviously a new entrant sort of in the field,
comparatively to a lot of organizations out there. What's really funny from our company journey
is that it's a microcosm sort of of the industry. You know, when we founded SpecterOps, I don't
think anybody would have accused us of some, like, super grand vision. Really the vision for us was
very inward focused. You know, we primarily were just focusing on ourselves and, like, being a place
that we wanted to work, being a place that did a few things well, and let our voice out there,
how we speak to sort of the community and the industry, be through our work, or let it speak
for itself. And be a place that people could be, you know, we felt we could be proud of the work
we were doing, but also feel rewarded for it, right? So very focused on ourselves. If there
was a vision, which maybe I'm being a little bit generous, but if there was a vision, you know, we
we felt fundamentally, and still do today, and you'll hear this quite a bit, but we felt
fundamentally that, you know, information sharing needs to be more open in our community. We need
to be more open about how we're building off of each other. Something that we were passionate
about beforehand, and when you run the company, right, you get to sort of lead by example, and try
to push that. Another thing maybe, again, being generous to some degree, maybe in our heart we
were sort of educators, you know, come from backgrounds of doing hundreds of engagements,
and I think anybody can relate to this kind of hamster wheel of, you know, constantly doing a
service, and coming back the next year, and the same thing, and really wondering, like,
what kind of impact are you having out there? And for us, for our passion, kind of was driven more
by, you know, educating, and getting satisfaction from, like, spreading that knowledge
out, and teaching, and building internal capabilities, so that they could do that. They could scale much
better than we can, maybe, you know, provide, you know, actually really push capabilities forward.
I wouldn't, I would never accuse those necessarily of being strategies,
but maybe our ethos beyond just being someplace that we kind of wanted to work, you can tell
it's not like there's a grand plan in there at all. And I think, you know, I know this is
speaking for me, but I think anybody who's gone out and been a part of building a company,
one of the things you realize early on, and that continues probably for forever, is that building
a company is really hard. Like, it just, there's, it's incredibly difficult. I hope I never found
another company. And you're often sort of doing that same thing I was talking about from the
industry, is that you're reacting. You're reacting to this much more, you know, external
sort of opportunities or challenges, and you get wrapped up in this day-to-day of just reacting.
So, you kind of sit yourself and, you know, look at what have we been doing for the last year, and
if you have a strategic plan or not, that's like, well, I mean, I don't know, didn't really hit it.
I mean, but we did all these things. And, you know, I think we were really fortunate for ourselves,
and probably lots in the industry felt very similar, and that it was the opportunities,
right, it was the former things that really were driving us a lot. So, it wasn't necessarily all
the challenges that we're facing. It's that, you know, we're in this growing industry,
and reminds me of a story I once heard from somebody who built and sold a company, a tech
company, in the late 90s. And kind of the point of the whole story was him saying, like, don't
think I'm all that smart, even though I pulled a company for a bunch of money, because in the
late 90s in the tech industry, you basically had to try not to make money. So, you know,
it was just lucky. In a lot of respects, I think that's true for cybersecurity as well,
but it has been for some time, not quite so much in 2020. But, you know, you're driven by this
external growing industry. You might say, like, oh, we grew 300% this year. Are we doing great?
Well, everybody's growing 300% because of the industry. It's not necessarily because you're
doing anything all that great. But it's really easy to lose kind of the forest and the trees,
right? You know, you have these overarching goals you want to hit, but then it's just the day-to-day
that catches up. We also, I think a lot of folks can relate, but we made plenty of mistakes along
the way as we were essentially doing everything for the first time. You find this sort of
accumulates in these, like, shaky supports sort of as you build the foundation, right? And so,
like, you got to go back and clean that up, which adds to the also we're driven by this
day-to-day opportunities. And so, you can sit here three and a half years later, kind of like I was,
and kind of say, how do we push forward to that? Like, we had these sort of dreams, at least,
when we started, and we certainly have tried to pursue them. But, you know, how well have we
really done at the end of the day? And you can look at yourself critically that way. But I think
we did learn a lot. And I would not say that we did everything wrong by any means. But I think
sometimes you look back and say, what have we not been good at? Oftentimes, for us, it's been
messaging. It's probably mostly been on me. But, you know, messaging and being out there and kind
of letting people know what you're doing and why are you doing it. You know, I don't think we've
often sort of been very quiet in that regard as we've gone along in our journey.
And what strikes me, sort of, when I look at this industry I've been a part of for so long,
if my younger self was to see us today, I think that person would be really disappointed.
Hopefully not at me, but, or at me, but sort of, like, how far did we come?
And, you know, if you look at us, every year, like, more and more money has been poured into
cybersecurity. Our industry has grown. Investments have been made in, you know, company, in the
cybersecurity practices and companies all over the place. But fair or not, or really, on us or not,
I have to say that I don't think we would argue that the world is a safer place, you know, after
the time that we've been doing this. People are more and more dependent on the technology and the
platforms that we're supposed to protect. And I think if we were successful, it would just,
you'd never hear from us, right? It would work. It wouldn't be something that you worry about,
you know, outside of the industry that we work in.
But that's not the case, right? Instead of working behind the scenes, actually, our struggles,
our defeats, our victories, even, are constantly out in the open and often really ill understood
by, you know, because they're fairly complex. And if you think of the victories, for example,
that do make it out in the open, and we're going to equate that to anything else, you kind of feel
sad for them. Like the victory was, you know, the fact that we were able to do it, you know,
like the victory was, you didn't have this, you know, system, or this, you know, collection of
systems broken into that were critical, which is great. It's wonderful. But like, it's like
the equivalent of like, you know, you're reading a newspaper, like we hold, we held the fort.
Most of the time we don't, but we did this time. That's actually kind of sad, right?
More than anything else, I think that there's this,
there's even more uncertainty. And if the investments we're making, and we're making a lot,
if what we're doing is effective, right? Is it, is, is this money that we're putting in,
and, you know, the people that were working here and whatever, like, are we effective? Are we
making it better? And in my experience, the answer is, well, I don't know, right? I mean,
we can have all kinds of metrics out there, but fundamentally, when it, you know, comes down to
the end, are we more effective? Do we feel more effective at responding to breaches? Do we have
confidence in ourselves, in our defenses? And I think the answer is oftentimes, no, right?
And so, you know, that's not necessarily a terrible thing,
but it's almost one of those things that you might, we might want to stop and say, okay, well,
how are we going to effectively utilize pretty, pretty massive resources that are deployed out
here for us? But if you look at our community, you know, our community, it really does face
these incredible challenges. You think about it, you have these massive investments that are being
made by our adversaries. And again, adversaries can be somewhat subjective, but, you know,
massive investments that are being made and, you know, to defeat us, to defeat effectively what
we as a public community are trying to do. And like I said, who's the good guys and who's the
bad guys? Somewhat up for debate. And so, we often have to operate in sort of like,
infiltrators are somewhat in our midst, right? Like the things that we're doing could be used
against us. And I think that as with any group of people that are sort of, you know, under siege,
develop sort of a bunker mentality in a lot of respects, or, you know, like exiles, you know,
war zone, and that we're under this incredible pressure a lot. But instead of unifying,
oftentimes, we won't break into, you know, warring factions, you know, fighting each other,
and sort of hoarding our scarce resources, right? Hoarding the fact that like,
each of us individually aren't really able to make that much of an investment compared to,
you know, nation state, along those lines. But we also hoard them to a large extent, because we
look like a source of competitive advantage or whatever, which just makes us collectively,
I think, less capable. On the plus side, like I said, our industry is incredibly dynamic.
And that's a really exciting thing for us to be in. I mean, even putting bounds around it,
as I said, is difficult. But, you know, the potential is still out there. Even if we feel
a little bit cynical today, and wouldn't never want to characterize us as a bunch of failures,
by any means, but like, we do have this dynamic element to us. And we can be very,
very good at solving collective problems and sort of get our get our heads around it.
You know, when we look at where we're going, as an industry, again, wouldn't call myself any kind
of philosopher, honestly, we make a lot better operators at Spectrops than prognosticators or
whatever. You know, there's lots of people out there with some very good opinions, people who
spend a lot of time and thought, they're trying to push the industry. And honestly, our perspective
is pretty inward focusing on things that we do. But some thoughts on where we feel
we'd like to see the industry go. And also where we'll try to push things.
You know, right off the top, let's say, we feel very strongly in this concept,
you know, that our industry, and our companies, you know, have this sort of dual mission.
And we sort of serve two masters. Because obviously, we're capitalists, and that's how
sort of the system works, whether you like it or not. But we also serve a public good.
Right, we're not just there to make money, we're also there to try to provide a line of defense
at the end of the day. And, you know, that's not unique, necessarily. In fact, there's lots
of industries out there that, you know, that have these dual purposes, maybe best example would be
healthcare, again, not trying to take a stance in healthcare by any means, or whether that's
effective or not for the various systems out there. If you think about it fundamentally,
there's an understanding and a sharing that happens within that industry in that community,
you don't necessarily see in an industry like ours. If you think about it, for example,
if one hospital system develops a technique that, you know, a surgical technique, let's just say,
that saves lives, that will make people safer, they don't hoard that, they don't hold it close
to their chest and say, you know, well, that's an advantage for us that we keep people alive
better than you do. They share it out, right? So that others can emulate them. They don't share
everything, obviously. But in some aspects of the industry, you might say, you know,
are a lot more about profit or IP protections or whatnot than others. But even those, I think you
see a level of sharing that you often don't see at the corporate level for us. I wouldn't
characterize the community level necessarily as the same. I think we have a great community,
but the corporate participation in that could not be that great.
I think there's a saying in the military, you train for the situations that you pray
you'll never face, right? This concept of readiness, that we need to be constantly
training and constantly getting ready for the thing we actually hope we never face.
And we would say that that focus on readiness needs to be probably better out there in the
security, within security operations as well. Because honestly, it's the exact same thing.
Think about it. Most of the situations that you're trying to protect against are the ones
or trying to be able to effectively react to are the ones you never actually want to face.
But you still want to be effective at them.
I think most importantly, though, something that's close for us is that we need to
remember that we're in the gates together and our enemies are outside those gates.
Our enemies are outside the gates, not inside with us. This isn't about red versus blue.
This isn't about your company or our company. This is about the collective thing we're trying
to do, the collective mission that we have. And maybe we do something that somebody else
doesn't like. Maybe we have an opinion that somebody doesn't like. Maybe we make a mistake
and we need help in addressing that and going forward in a better direction.
But it needs to come from a position that we're all still in this together. We're all here to
help each other. And our enemies are not us. We're not a group of warring factions.
I don't have much more to say on that. But for us, that's something that's very important.
And you'll see from us is that that's not a side that we're going to try to take.
When I look at SpectreOps today, ironically, I've found for myself, personally,
and as our company has grown, that we're more defined by our limitations than we were by our
ambitions. I don't mean that necessarily in a negative way, but you become much more aware of
what you can actually achieve versus the kind of grand dreams you might have.
And we know that our company isn't going to change the world or change the industry.
We're a small cog in a big system at the end of the day. It doesn't mean we're helpless.
It just means that there are things that we can affect and things that we can't affect.
We've done some things right, but we've also often fallen short of our own dreams.
At our worst, we can become paralyzed with our inaction, worried about the negative perception
that our customers might have, the community might have of something we're doing,
and sit there and ruminate over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over.
And sit there and ruminate over and over again on what the right answer might be.
And then, until it doesn't really matter what the right answer is,
because you just didn't do anything and you moved on.
I think when I look at us, at least from an engagement perspective,
that's probably one of our biggest failings, is falling short of where we wanted to be.
But it's not negative. I don't want people to think that I sit here and think quite negatively
about our industry or company or anything else. I have great hope for our industry.
I have great hope, obviously, for our company. And I'd like to say, where are we going to go?
What can you expect from us as you look to us in the future?
I won't say about some specific business or some tool we're going to release,
but more our philosophy. For us, we're going to be always conscious of our dual mission.
Cognizant that we serve a public good, along with trying to also make payroll,
whatever else we're up to. And that means that we're not necessarily going to
every time make the decision that makes us the most money, right?
That we have two masters at the end of the day that we're going to be serving.
And we encourage others to look at it that same way.
Yeah, it doesn't mean we're not in competition, but it does mean that we understand what we
share and we don't share. And what collectively pushes us,
makes us collectively better. And we're not going to have all the answers.
We don't have all the answers now, even to most of the questions we have.
I'm sure we have a few of the answers, but we're going to be comfortable with that.
The fact that we don't necessarily know where this goes.
And we're not going to try to determine whatever that answer is before we decide to take action.
What you can expect to see from us is this sort of continual focus on an educational mission,
that thing that makes us passionate and being open with information sharing, being maybe more
open today as we look at what have we been sharing or not as we've gone through our day-to-day
struggles and whatnot. I think, you know, we're going to have to figure out how we're going to
being, we're going to work on being more comfortable in our own skin, trying to lead by
example, but being okay with wearing a blouse on our sleeve. And, you know, we're going to make
mistakes. We're going to make a lot of mistakes, but as long as we're learning from them, that's
okay. It's a good part of the process. And it's not a failure, you know, for us others to see that.
I think also, you know, as long as we're going to default to action, right? Like,
like at the end of the day, the worst decision is the ones that you don't make.
And so sometimes when you make those decisions on what you're going to release,
what you're going to share, the stance that you're going to take,
people might not like what you did. They might think that you didn't really consider,
you know, every opinion enough, or you didn't consider all the angles enough.
And it could be, it could be right in that case. And we're going to understand that sometimes the
work, sometimes the work that we produce is not going to be used for good, right? It's going to
be used against us. We can't control everything, but the trade-off is ignorance. And to us,
we feel that's more negative than the times that the things that we've done have been used against
us. Probably I'll have to stay there. Hopefully, you know, again, that's pretty vague because
it's not like we're talking about a business strategic plan necessarily, but at least maybe
you understand, like, how do we see the world? How do we see our interactions with the world?
What are we going to advocate for? And we'll try to be better as we look into the future with,
you know, that being open with that message and being more open with what we're saying.
I'd like to close with a couple things. One is, you know, again, I want to thank everyone
who signed up for this event. You know, the responses were sort of overwhelming for us,
and I think really reaffirming for us, you know, sort of positivity as we were dealing
